question: Which of the following was the oldest person on their first launch into space?
success: Correct! Michael Melvill was 63 when he visited the International Space Station in 2003

hint.text: Explore the infographic. You can change the order of the astronauts using the options at the top of the page. Each circle represents an astronaut and clicking on one will give you more information about them.

question: Which two astronauts have each made more launches into space than anyone else?
success: Correct! Both Jerry Ross and Franklin Chang-Diaz have completed seven launches into space.

hint.text: Explore the infographic. You can change the order of the astronauts using the options at the top of the page.

question: Which of these astronauts was born furthest North?
success: Correct! AlthoughBjarni Tryggvason has Canadian nationality, he was actually born in Iceland.

question: What was the first mission to encounter Mercury?
success: Yes - Mariner 10 completed three flybys of Mercury in the 1970s

hint.text: Explore the infographic. The missions are listed in date order moving outward from the planet.

question: Which two Solar System bodies did the Deep Space 1 probe visit?

hint.text: Explore the infographic. Click on the lines to identify the missions.

question: Which was the first comet to be encountered by a spacecraft?
success: Correct! The Giotto mission made a distant flyby of 21P/Giacobini-Zinner on its way to its main target, comet 1P/Halley

hint.text: Explore the infographic. The missions that have returned to Earth have a second line returning to Earth.

question: Which planet has a tropopause at the highest pressure?

hint.text: Explore the infographic. The tropopauses are all labelled, and clicking on them will show the pressure

question: Which planet's atmosphere has the lowest temperature at an altitude of 100km
success: Correct! Uranus differs from the other outer planets in that it has no internal heat source. No one know why!

hint.text: Explore the infographic. You can click the buttons at the top to set the same altitude on all the planets.

question: On which of these solar system bodies could you jump the highest?
success: Correct! Although Pluto is larger than some of the other objects listed, it's much less massive, so has weaker surface gravity

hint.text: Explore the infographic. There's no shortcut - you've just got to try jumping on all those objects!

question: Which small object was the last to be classified as a planet before the category of asteroid was used?
Which two moons of Saturn, initially classified as planets, were discovered in the same year
When will the Sun next be closest to the barycentre of the Solar System?
success: Correct! The Sun will next pass closest to barycentre of the Solar System in 2030. (If you're reading this after 2030, the apologies for not updating this!)

question: Which of these constellations contains the most Messier objects?
success: Correct! Although it's not the largest constellation, Sagittarius contains a lot of star clusters and nebulae located between us and the centre of the Galaxy.

hint.text: Explore the infographic. Click on the constellations to see more information.

question: Which element is considered essential for life, but only created by radioactive decay?

hint.text: Explore the infographic. Use the toggles to turn on and off the different sources. [N.B. you need the updated online version to answer this!]

question: NGC objects with numbers in the range 1700 to 2500 predominantly include what types of objects
success: Correct! This range of numbers in the NGC catalogue includes regions towards the centre of our Galaxy, so is dominated by star clusters and groups.

question: Which of the following people was a prolific discoverer of novae?
success: Correct! Williamina Flemming discovered around 40% of the novae known at the time.

hint.text: Explore the infographic. Click on the images to find out more about the people.
